en_results_raw: and sometimes, I must confess, in a total misapprehension of their intentions, which, when discovered, has led to a most mortifying sense of my own folly. I have often found myself in situations where I have misjudged a person's character, only to be surprised by their true nature, and I must admit that it has been a valuable lesson in humility. It has taught me to be more cautious in my judgments and to look beyond the surface level, for it is often the quiet and unassuming individuals who possess the greatest depth and wisdom. In fact, I have come to realize that true character is not always revealed by grand gestures or loud declarations, but rather by the small, everyday actions and decisions that speak volumes about a person's heart and intentions. And so, I have learned to approach each new acquaintance with a sense of curiosity and openness, rather than making assumptions or jumping to conclusions, for it is in these moments of genuine connection and understanding that we often discover the most about ourselves and others.

en_first_half: "It is very true," said Marianne, "that admiration of landscape scenery is become a mere jargon. Every body pretends to feel and tries to describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what picturesque beauty
en_second_half: was. I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and meaning."
en_results: is to be, and who first taught others to see it. They quote his descriptions, and repeat his opinions, without either doing him the justice of understanding them, or themselves feeling the truth of them.
en_results_raw: is to be, and who first taught others to see it. They quote his descriptions, and repeat his opinions, without either doing him the justice of understanding them, or themselves feeling the truth of them. They talk of his having opened their eyes to the beauties of nature, till one would be led to suppose that before his time, the world was altogether destitute of such beauties, or that no one had ever beheld the sun shine, or the rain fall, or the leaves bud, or the flowers bloom, till he appeared to point out these wonders to them. But, in fact, the truth is, that the world was never more sensible of the beauties of nature than it is at present; and that the only difference is, that now every body is more aware of them, and more anxious to describe them, than they were before. The consequence is, that the language of landscape scenery has become so much affected, so much strained, and so much overloaded with words of high-sounding names, that it is become almost unintelligible to those who are not accustomed to it. The terms of picturesque beauty, of sublimity, of grandeur, of majesty, of beauty, of elegance, of taste, and of refinement, are used so loosely, and so indiscriminately, that they have lost all their original meaning, and are now employed merely to express the speaker's own feelings, or to display his own knowledge, rather than to convey any distinct or intelligible idea. And thus, instead of being a means of communicating our thoughts and feelings to others, the language of landscape scenery has become a mere jargon, a set of words, which, though they may sound well, convey no meaning, and are used only to gratify the speaker's own vanity, or to impress his hearers with a false idea of his own importance.

La admiración por la naturaleza es algo que se ha vuelto común, pero la capacidad de expresarla con la belleza y la profundidad que lo hace verdaderamente especial es algo que pocos logran. La mayoría de las personas se limitan a repetir frases hechas y a copiar la forma en que otros han expresado sus sentimientos, sin realmente comprender el significado detrás de sus palabras. en_results: It was a habit so firmly established, that the arrival of the family at Barton Park was always a signal for a little ceremony, which, though trifling in itself, was of
en_results_raw: It was a habit so firmly established, that the arrival of the family at Barton Park was always a signal for a little ceremony, which, though trifling in itself, was of some importance to the ladies, as it gave them an opportunity of displaying their new gowns, and of hearing the opinions of their friends on their appearance. Sir John was a man of considerable fortune, and his table was always abundantly supplied with the finest delicacies, which made his invitations highly coveted by the neighbourhood. The Dashwoods, however, were not among the most eager of his guests, for they were not fond of large parties, and preferred the quiet enjoyment of each other's society to the noise and bustle of a crowded assembly. But Sir John's kindness and good nature were such, that they could not refuse his invitations without offending him, and they therefore accepted his offers with a mixture of pleasure and reluctance, knowing that they would have to endure the company of his boisterous and talkative friends, who were always ready to engage in lively discussions and to make merry at the expense of others.

en_results_raw: be no part; and she was not disposed to make any allowance for the difference. Her sister's tranquility, she thought, was a proof of her want of sensibility; and she could not help sometimes feeling a little vexed at the calmness with which Elinor met the news of Edward's engagement. It was a calmness which she could not herself command, and which she did not at all understand; but she was determined to make no further inquiry into its cause, and to endeavour to reconcile herself to the change in her sister's situation, as soon as possible. She knew that Elinor was not one to be easily swayed by her feelings, and that she would not be influenced by any thing which she did not thoroughly believe to be right; but she could not help sometimes wishing that her sister's attachment to Edward had been a little stronger, and that she had not been so ready to give him up. She knew that she would never be able to like Lucy Steele, and that she would always consider her as a rival, but she was determined to make an effort to be civil to her, and to treat her with the respect due to her as Edward's wife. She was not, however, very successful in this attempt, and she found it difficult to speak to Lucy without some degree of coldness and reserve, which she knew was not very becoming in her, but which she could not help feeling. She was, however, determined to make the best of it, and to endeavour to be as agreeable as possible to her sister's husband, and to his wife, and to make their visit to Barton as pleasant as she could.

The air was thick with the scent of decay and rot, and I could feel the weight of years of secrets bearing down upon me. I wandered through the musty halls, my footsteps echoing off the walls, until I came upon a door that seemed out of place. It was small, with a delicate handle in the shape of a snail, and it seemed to be calling to me. I turned the handle, and a faint light spilled out, illuminating the darkened hallway. I stepped inside, and found myself in a room filled with strange and wondrous objects, each one more bizarre than the last. There were taxidermied animals with glassy eyes, and ancient artifacts that seemed to hold secrets of a long-forgotten world. I felt a shiver run down my spine, as I realized that I was not alone in the mansion. I heard a faint whispering in my ear, a soft voice that seemed to be saying my name. I spun around, but there was no one there. The voice grew louder, more insistent, and I felt a presence closing in around me. I tried to run, but my feet seemed rooted to the spot. And then, everything went black.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

vi_first_half: - Tư cách của anh giờ được đặt trước mặt cô - xa hoa, phóng đãng, và còn tệ hại hơn cả hai. Khi đã biết được tất cả - vì tôi đã biết được nhiều tuần rồi - cô thử đoán tôi đã nghĩ gì khi nhìn thấy em gái cô vẫn thân ái với anh ấy như bao giờ; và khi được tin em gái cô sẽ cưới anh ấy, thử đoán tôi đã nghĩ gì cho cô ấy. "Tuần rồi khi tôi đến đây và thấy cô chỉ có một mình, tôi đến với chủ định tìm hiểu sự thật; tuy không rõ mình sẽ làm gì một khi đã biết sự thật đau lòng. Lúc ấy cử chỉ của tôi hẳn là kỳ lạ đối với cô, nhưng bây giờ cô đã hiểu tại sao. Làm cho hai cô đau khổ thấy bị lừa dối như thế; thấy em gái cô... nhưng tôi làm gì được? Tôi không hy vọng ngăn cản được cuộc hôn nhân, và đôi lúc tôi nghĩ ảnh hưởng của em gái cô sẽ cảm hóa được anh ta." "Nhưng bây giờ, sau những sự lợi dụng ô nhục như thế, ai mà nói được anh toan tính những gì với em gái cô. Tuy nhiên, bất luận các toan tính này là như thế nào, khi em gái cô so sánh hoàn cảnh của mình với hoàn cảnh của Eliza khốn khổ của tôi, khi biết qua tình trạng cùng khổ vả vô vọng của con bé đáng thương này, bây giờ
vi_second_half: em gái cô hẳn cảm thấy - sau này chắc chắn sẽ cảm thấy - là hoàn cảnh của mình còn may mắn. Em gái cô nên tưởng tượng mình là con bé kia; với tình cảm dành cho anh ta còn sâu đậm - cũng sâu đậm như chính tình cảm của em cô - với tư tưởng giằng xé vì tự trách mình, và tư tưởng này cứ vương vấn suốt đời. Chắc chắn so sánh này sẽ hữu ích cho em gái cô. Cô ấy sẽ thấy những khổ sở của mình không là gì cả. Đây chỉ là do hành vi sai lạc, chứ không làm ô nhục. Trái lại, các khổ sở này phải khiến mỗi bằng hữu của em gái cô trở thành bạn tốt hơn. Mối quan tâm tới bất hạnh của em gái cô, và lòng kính trọng cho sự chịu đựng bất hạnh này, phải cũng cố mọi quan hệ gắn bó." "Tuy nhiên, cô nên suy xét khi truyền đạt đến cô ấy những gì tôi đã kể cho cô nghe. Hẳn cô là người biết rõ hơn ai hết ảnh hưởng là như thế nào; nhưng nếu tôi đã không tin một cách nghiêm túc từ trong thâm tâm rằng mình có thể giúp ích, có thể xoa dịu tiếc nuối của em gái cô, thì tôi đã không chịu khổ sở để làm phiền cô vì câu chuyện đau buồn này trong gia đình tôi - có vẻ như với mục đích đề cao tôi và hạ nhục người khác."

es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Sabiéndolo, como yo lo he sabido desde hace ya muchas semanas, imagínese lo que debo haber sentido al ver a su hermana tan afecta a él como siempre, y cuando se me aseguró que iba a casarse con él; imagínese lo que habré sentido pensando en todas ustedes. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.

She would see the look of satisfaction on Mrs. Dashwood's face, when she returned from her walk, and she would feel a sense of duty fulfilled, in being able to contribute to the comfort of those around her. But as the days went by, she started to realize that she was not just going out for the sake of others, but also for her own sake, and the fresh air and exercise were beginning to bring a new sense of vitality to her life.

She watched him walk away, his tall figure disappearing into the crowd, and felt a sense of relief wash over her, knowing that she had done the right thing in letting him go. As she turned to re-enter the house, she couldn't help but think about the conversation they had just had, and the way he had spoken about his feelings for her, and she felt a pang of regret for not being able to return his affections, but she knew that it was for the best, and that she had to prioritize her own happiness, and the happiness of her family, above all else.

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."

es_first_half: —Sí, una vez, cuando estaba alojada en esta casa. Me había dejado caer por unos diez minutos, y me bastó con lo que vi de ella. Una simple muchacha pueblerina, desmañada, sin estilo ni elegancia, y casi sin ningún atractivo. La recuerdo perfectamente. Justo el tipo de muchacha que habría creído capaz de cautivar al pobre Edward. Apenas mi madre me contó todo el asunto, de inmediato me ofrecí— a hablarle, a disuadirlo de la unión; pero, según pude darme cuenta, ya era demasiado tarde para hacer algo, pues por desgracia no estuve ahí en los primeros momentos y no supe nada
es_second_half: de lo ocurrido hasta después de la ruptura, cuando, ya sabe usted, no me correspondía interferir. Pero si se me hubiera informado unas pocas horas antes, probablemente habría podido hacer algo. De todas maneras le habría hecho ver las cosas a Edward con toda claridad. “Mi querido amigo”, le habría dicho, “piensa en lo que haces. Estás comprometiéndote en la más desafortunada unión, que toda tu familia desaprueba de manera unánime”. En fin, no puedo evitar pensar que habría encontrado alguna manera de lograrlo. Pero ahora es demasiado tarde. Debe estar muerto de hambre, sabe usted; con toda seguridad, absolutamente muerto de hambre.
